review_title: Great people within programme overshadowed by incompetent senior management
job_title: Student Social Worker in London, England
pros: Practice tutor and CSW (consultant social worker)/manager were so lovely and amazing. Everyone I met on the actual programme were so kind, friendly and helpful. A lot of support here.
cons:
Actual management of Frontline is incompetent. Complete disregard to the risks they are putting their graduate cohort in with Covid, and when concern is expressed there is no room to change anything. I was sent to do direct work with a family without PPE and was informed midway through that they were isolating from Covid. This is fine, part of the job. The problem came after when I requested an intercalated (differed) offer due to health reasons and caring responsibilities, and was rejected on grounds that failed to account for cultural differences (I grew up in a different country) and mental distress caused by the near-miss incidents. I was not given the chance to videochat the person in charge of my request, and felt I was not given any chance at all. There is also no room to appeal the decision. After my intercalation offer, I had to withdraw from the programme due to my inability to do things in person and without social distancing. 

Precautionary rules put in place e.g. maintain 2 metres distance from families are just formalities. Frontline writes them down just to protect themselves in case you catch Covid. 

Overall, I am glad I left when I did as Frontline's management was unsatisfactory and soon after I left my whole team was placed at risk when someone within Frontline caught Covid.

review_title: Hard not to be biased, but my honest reflections…
pros:
As a current and long-standing director at Frontline I am likely to be at least a little bit biased. However, here are my honest views, with which I have tried to be as balanced as possible…
•	Strong sense of purpose and that everyone’s work contributes to the mission
•	Great office in a leafy, peaceful location, surrounded by mission-aligned organisations (I work in the London Office and from home)
•	Colleagues who care about each other, celebrate each other’s successes and are motivated to improve things
•	Highly flexible working culture that values outcomes and provides the autonomy to achieve them
•	Lots of opportunities and support for developing new skills
cons:
•	Offices are very open plan and work style is highly agile – some people will love this but it doesn’t suit everyone
•	You are trusted and supported to make good decisions but there’s not always a document, policy or protocol to tell you what to do, which can be challenging at first

job_title: Firstline Programmer Officer in London, England
pros:
Just finished 2 years working at Frontline, and can confirm it's the most welcoming, hard-working and collaborative office I've ever worked at. The biggest positives I'd pick out are 
- the culture of 'freedom & responsibility' that's been embedded throughout the organisation, with a focus on giving and receiving feedback at all levels, celebrating mistakes and the learning that comes from them, and replacing excessive process with trust and autonomy for staff. 
- a real investment in staff development, with quality training offered internally and externally. I've received training in project and events management, unconscious biases and Social GRACES amongst others
- the whole organisation, from SLT down to new starters, are driven by the mission of improving outcomes for vulnerable children and families. This drives the charity forward and creates a common goal that encourages collaborative leadership
cons: I think one of the challenges with a large charity where the majority of the staff resources are focused on one programme, is that the other smaller programmes can feel slightly neglected at times. I've given this feedback and am aware that the organisation are taking steps to address this challenge.

pros: Frontline are striving to build a culture which focusses on freedom and responsibility. In brief, this is the freedom to pursue your own ideas and work streams, with the responsibility that you are accountable to them. This looks like: defining your own priorities, working on things you think are impactful (within your role), giving and accepting constructive feedback, and working on yourself. Frontline has the strongest and best culture of anywhere I have worked and sets a great example for the rest of the third sector to follow. Expect to be challenged and grow enormously, while being invested in your work.
cons: The organisation often uses language about people which can feel alienating - at times, I didn't feel 'outstanding' or 'talented'. I would encourage folk reading this to apply for roles whether or not you identify with the terms the organisation uses! Imposter syndrome is real but you've got to be in it to win it.
